prs.l: transitive verb sense 2a and intransitive verb sense 1 usually

dt: {bc}to purchase (goods, services, etc.) on a contract basis

dt.t: He {wi}contracted{/wi} his armies into one force

dt: {bc}to reduce to smaller size by or as if by squeezing or forcing together
{bc}to shorten (a word) by omitting one or more sounds or letters

dt.t: The builder {wi}contracted{/wi} with them to build a deck.

dt: {bc}to draw together so as to become diminished in size
{bc}to become less in compass, duration, or length

pt: {sc}contract{/sc} {sc}shrink{/sc} {sc}condense{/sc} {sc}compress{/sc} {sc}constrict{/sc} {sc}deflate{/sc} mean to decrease in bulk or volume. {sc}contract{/sc} applies to a drawing together of surfaces or particles or a reduction of area or length.
{sc}shrink{/sc} implies a contracting or a loss of material and stresses a falling short of original dimensions.
{sc}condense{/sc} implies a reducing of something homogeneous to greater compactness without significant loss of content.
{sc}compress{/sc} implies a pressing into a small compass and definite shape usually against resistance.
{sc}constrict{/sc} implies a tightening that reduces diameter.

pt.t: the throat is {it}constricted{/it} by a tight collar

pt: {sc}deflate{/sc} implies a contracting by reducing the internal pressure of contained air or gas.

et: Middle English, from Middle French or Latin; Middle French {it}contracter{/it} to agree upon, from Latin {it}contractus{/it} {dx_ety}see {dxt|contract:1||}{/dx_ety}
shortdef: to bring on oneself especially inadvertently : incur
to establish or undertake by contract
